metadata.case_name: Legal Representatives of A. R. Rangachari v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Appeals by legal representatives of A. R. Rangachari, who died during pendency in Madras High Court of reference under s. 66(1) of Income-tax Act by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras Bench.
Question referred to High Court: Whether the inclusion in the assessee's total income of the profits settled by him on his wife and two daughters is justified in law?
High Court answered the question in the affirmative.
Rangachari was one of five partners of firm Messrs. Chari and Ram, holding six-anna share in profits and losses.

On September 22, 1947, Rangachari executed three deeds of settlement (Exts. A, A-1, A-2) in favour of wife, married adult daughter, and minor daughter, assigning to each one-fourth share of his profits from the firm (but not losses) for 8 years, vesting absolute and exclusive right, irrevocable.
Deed terms: Settlor assigns one-fourth share of profits payable to him, to be taken and enjoyed absolutely; settlor has no right; beneficiary entitled to receive directly from firm; irrevocable.
For assessment year 1947-48 (previous year ending April 13, 1947), profits to Rangachari Rs. 86,491-13-0, credited to his account; Rs. 21,622-15-3 (one-fourth) transferred to each disponee.
Profits of previous year ending April 13, 1948, disposed similarly.
Assessee claimed amounts could not be included in his total income, excluded by third proviso to s. 16(1)(c); diverted by overriding title per Bijoy Singh Dudhuria v. CIT.

Income-tax Officer rejected: For 1947-48, deeds executed after close of previous year, income accrued; transfer to minor daughter within s. 16(3), no adequate consideration; for wife and married daughter, s. 16(1)(c) not applicable as income accrued to assessee first.
Assessee's appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal failed.
High Court held s. 16(1)(c) did not apply, third proviso not attracted; income accrued to assessee first, then applied to payments.

legal_issues.text: Whether the inclusion in the assessee's total income of the profits settled by him on his wife and two daughters is justified in law?

petitioner_arguments.text: Amounts could not be included in assessee's total income, being excluded by third proviso to s. 16(1)(c) of Income-tax Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Third proviso to s. 16(1)(c), Income-tax Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Amount payable to wife and daughters never became assessee's income, diverted by overriding title.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bijoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal (1933) 1 I.T.R. 135

petitioner_arguments.text: What assigned was actionable claim (right to profits), so profits diverted before accruing to disponer.

respondent_arguments.text: For 1947-48, income accrued before deeds executed; transfer to minor under s. 16(3), no adequate consideration.
s. 16(1)(c) not applicable as transferred income first accrued to assessee.
Income accrued to assessee first, then applied to payments under deeds.

court_reasoning.text: s. 16(1)(c) did not apply; third proviso not attracted; income accrued to assessee first, then applied to disponees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deeds created right to receive from firm, but profits accrue to partner first under partnership law.

court_reasoning.text: Recent cases (Provat Kumar Mitter, Tulsidas Kilachand, CIT v. Sitaldas Tirathdas) directly bearing: rule in Bijoy Singh applies only where income diverted by overriding title never becoming assessee's.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not governed by s. 16(1)(c) or Bijoy Singh rule.

court_reasoning.text: Under partnership law, only partner entitled to profits; stranger/assignee has no direct claim.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not an actionable claim diverting profits before accrual.

holdings.text: Inclusion of settled profits in assessee's total income justified; no application of s. 16(1)(c) or diversion by overriding title.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bijoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule applies only where income diverted by overriding title never becoming assessee's income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Provat Kumar Mitter v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Transfer of dividends from assessee's shares to wife not within s. 16(1)(c) or Bijoy Singh rule.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tulsidas Kilachand v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Trust of shares to pay dividends to wife governed by s. 16(3)(b), not s. 16(1)(c).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Sitaldas Tirathdas
precedents_cited.relevance: Bijoy Singh rule considered with P.C. Mullick; applies only to overriding title diverting income before accrual.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. C. Mullick v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Considered along with Bijoy Singh on diversion by overriding title.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.66(1); third proviso to s.16(1)(c) not applicable; s.16(3) for minor transfer.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed affirming High Court; inclusion of profits settled on wife and daughters in assessee's total income justified as profits accrued to assessee first under partnership law, no diversion by overriding title or application of s.16(1)(c).

key_quotes.text: "the profits were first to accrue to him and were then applied for payments to the disponees."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on accrual of income before settlement.

key_quotes.text: "Under the law of partnership, it is the partner and the partner alone who is entitled to the profits."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why no direct claim by disponees, rejecting actionable claim argument.

key_quotes.text: "These three cases, in our opinion, afford a complete answer to the contentions of the appellants."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Relies on recent SC precedents to dispose of appeal.
